title: What is the average price to pay for a bk 13 and bk 7 to lawyers in the bay area?
question: what is the initial cost, one-time fee or total cost for a bk13 and bk7?
answers:
Just go on the internet and you will see prices all the way from $125 for BK form preparation to $495 plus filing fees to $2500 for 'No look" fees in several of the Districts, including and excluding filing fees.....OR....Do it yourself with NOLO PRESS publisher at your public library for a step by step instructions that will get most ordinary filers thru the process if nothing unusual comes up. There is an additional service available that debtors can pay $100 and have access to the author via email.

C13 is the territory of professionals. 4 out of 5 C13's are dismissed without discharge unless an attorney is involved. Fees will vary from $1500 for very little and simple core cases up to $6500 'No Look" fees that cover or have a couple of real estate properties and or business, auto, taxes, etc. Big advantage is that the attorney fees can be paid monthly as part of the Plan and some districts the attorney is paid before the creditors.

Not everyone qualifies for C13. Not everyone qualifies for C7; it is a tangled web of Rule, Procedures, and the Process can take months for a C7 or years (up to 5 for C13).....so
make sure you like the professional you choose. Know them, like them, and trust them.

I completely agree with the prior response, but will add the following: Chapter 7 cases are usually fixed fee cases. Chapter 13 allows for some of the attorneys fees to be taken over time through the monthly plan payments, but this is subject to the specifics of the case (such as the amount of the monthly payment, whether there are sufficient funds available to pay priority debts which need to be repaid 100% through the plan, etc.)

In short, as was already said, everyone's situation is different and the facts and complexity of the case will dictate the cost. That said, attorneys' fees will of course vary, just like doctors charge different fees. I've said this before and I'll say it again: People don't generally bargain-shop for doctors and they shouldn't do it for attorneys--particularly ones that are helping you with your financial situation. You need it done right. That doesn't mean a less expensive attorney won't handle your case as well as a more expensive one, but your main criteria should be the quality of the attorney and how comfortable you are with them.

Mark J. Markus, Attorney at Law
http://www.bklaw.com/

I don't know of any average price, and I don't know how any attorney can quote a price without first discussing your situation with you. The complexity and time required for a Chapter 7 or Chapter 13 bankruptcy varies greatly from situation to situation.
